title: Plug Power Datacenter Narrative Likely BS $PLUG

transcript.text: Hello and welcome back to the Broken
Business Models podcast. We are your
hosts, Ryan and James. And before we get
into today's podcast, just a quick
disclaimer, nothing in this podcast or
any of our other material should be
taken as investment advice. James and I
could have positions in any of the
stocks we we may mention today and we
reserve the right to change those
positions at any time. So, always make
sure you do your own work and consult
with a professional before making any
investment decision. With that being
said, the topic of today's podcast is
going to be Plug Power.
So to start off, just a quick refresher,
Plug Power is a company who is in the
business in the business of hydrogen
fuel cells. So they create these
hydrogen fuel cell devices, which are
basically these little electronic
devices that take in hydrogen gas, so H2
gas, and then uh produce as output
electricity. So it is a electricity
storage solution similar to a
rechargeable battery where instead of
just storing the electricity in the
chemicals of the battery you store the
energy in the form of hydrogen gas and
then when you need the electricity you
run the hydrogen gas through the fuel
cell and it produces the electricity.
The problem is that in terms of the cost
of producing the hydrogen required to
generate one unit of electricity, it is
much much more expensive than a regular
rechargeable battery and thus is not
economically viable on any scale except
for very niche use cases. And so Plug
Power sells these hydrogen fuel cell
devices to customers. But they also have
to sell the hydrogen fuel itself at a
massive discount, significantly below
its own cost to produce the hydrogen in
order for it to make sense for any of
their customers to actually use these
hydrogen fuel cell devices. Otherwise,
they would just use a much cheaper
solution like a rechargeable battery. So
they sell the hydrogen fuel cell
devices. They also sell the hydrogen
fuel at below cost. And they also make a
little bit of revenue from selling from
the electricity generated by some of
their hydrogen fuel cells. Um as I
mentioned uh just now the entire system
is not economically viable and so plug
power basically subsidizes the entire
system and because of that they make
massive gross losses on all the revenue
that they generate.
Their financials are nothing short of
disastrous. So as you can see here in
this chart I have the quarterly revenue
and operating income of the company
going back uh a couple of years in
almost all quarters they burn something
something around 200 to $300 million in
operating losses which is on the same
order of magnitude as the amount of
revenue that they generate. So they're
losing about as much money in operating
losses as they make in revenue.
Over time, these losses have piled up
and in early 2025, they had to come to
terms with it um in some in some
capacity and so they initiated something
called Project Quantum Leap, which the
name Project Quantum Leap sounds like
something really exciting and really,
you know, really exciting for the
future, but in reality, it was just a
massive uh effort to cut costs and
reduce their their massive losses that
they're generating. So massive layoffs,
facilities consolidation, other types of
cost cuts, and also they they said they
were going to start increasing the
pricing of their hydrogen fuel that they
sell to customers. Uh if you remember, I
mentioned that they they sell hydrogen
fuel to their fuel cell customers at
below cost. So they said they're going
to try to increase the pricing of this
hydrogen fuel in order to recoup some of
those losses.
Despite that, their uh gross losses and
their cost of goods sold have continued
to be extremely extremely bad. In the re
in in the most recent quarter, their
cost of revenue and gross loss both
actually increased by $20 million versus
the year ago period, despite the fact
that they actually generated a little
bit less revenue than the year ago
period.
In terms of their financial position, at
the end of the most recent quarter, they
only had about $166 million of cash in
cash equivalents, which is less than one
quarter's worth of cash burn. They also
had to raise about $400 million in just
a few days ago in November of 2025 in
the form of convertible notes. Uh but
even after that cash raise, they still
have less than one year worth of cash.
So they're going to have to reduce costs
further uh increase revenue or raise
additional capital in order to avoid
bankruptcy.
So one last thing to mention about Plug
Power's background is um earlier this
month the stock briefly pumped had a
increase in share price due to something
that happened that is is related to the
current data center and AI narrative. So
they announced a non-binding letter of
intent with a data center company that
is currently building out data centers
across the country. And what's going to
happen is that current that plug power
previously had been planning to planning
a green hydrogen production facility in
New York uh for which they had
electricity purchase agreements with
electricity companies to power this
green hydrogen production facility. Um
this agreement with the data center
company is for uh Plug Power to
essentially cancel their plans to build
this green green hydrogen production
facility and divert those electricity uh
purchase contracts to the data center
companies to instead use the electricity
for their data centers. Um, so this
could potentially generate over $275
million for plug power, but it is
probably not going to amount to anything
because it's a non-binding letter of
intent and so most likely it's not going
to move the needle in either direction.
But something to mention uh because it
did affect the stock price briefly. So
with that being said, I'll kick it over
to you James to talk more about the
specifics of uh uh Plug Power's current
situation.
>> Yeah. So, first Ryan mentioned the
project quantum leap where Plug Power in
2025 was trying to reduce costs and
reduce the amount of money that they're
losing. And if we look at this chart of
their free cash flow each quarter, so
their quarterly cash burn, 2025 does
have a significant improvement over
2024, but they're still burning a lot of
cash. So in just the first nine months
they burn Plug Power burned $500
million, but that's still a huge cash
burn, but it's less cash than they
burned in 2024. So part of that is
indeed due to their cost cuts and
layoffs and such. However, another thing
we have to consider is that throughout
this period, their inventory decreased a
lot. So, they've been running down their
inventory um failing to produce new
hydrogen inventory. And that's a way
that they've tried to improve their cash
firm situation. However, that's not a
sustainable solution because if you're
just trying to improve your improve your
cash flow by reducing inventory,
eventually you run out of inventory and
there's some amount of inventory that
you need to actually run the business.
So, this is a temporary benefit of them
running down the inventory. and despite
them running down the inventory, they're
still burning a huge amount of cash. So
the core business is still is still
unviable and is still losing a lot of
money. Um so we need to we need to keep
that in mind as we analyze the company
further.
So in the early part in the first half
of 2025, that's when Plight Power was
talking about their project quantum leap
and they were saying, "Oh, we're going
to cut all these costs, do all these
layoffs, do all these other things, and
that's supposedly going to get us to
profitability." And one of the big, if
you follow Plug Power over the previous
years,
they have always, Plug Power has
incurred operating losses since
inception. And they have typically
funded their operating losses by selling
new shares of by selling new stock onto
the market. Basically, they use dilutive
equity raises to raise capital to fund
their cash burn. Now, in April of 2025,
they announced a loan that they had
secured a loan of up to $500 million.
And they said, "Now that we got this
loan, this is enough cash to get us
through the rest of the year." And at
the time in April of 2025, they said as
a result of them securing this loan,
Plug Power has no intention of raising
additional equity in 2025, underscoring
its focus on discipline capital
management. So just in April, they said
that we have enough money, we don't need
to sell more stock in 2025. Well, then
what happened in the third quarter of
2025? So just a few months after they
made that statement, what do they do?
They sell 29 million shares of stock to
raise $76 million. So they they're this
project quantum leap, this cost cutting
initiative that they had for 2025, it
has failed to deliver the intended
results. Plug Power is still losing an
obscene amount of money and they are
still obliged to do dilutive equity
raises to raise capital just to keep the
lights on.
And this you should the fact that they
said we don't need to sell stock and
then a few months later they sell a ton
of stock that just shows that whatever
management says whatever uh whatever
future projections and guidance that
plug powers management gives cannot be
trusted because they have such a
horrible track record of keeping their
promises.
Now back in like uh 2020 2021 when there
was this whole stock market bubble
during COVID related to green energy and
hydrogen and whatever poly power share
price was very high and they were able
to sell stock because their stock price
was so high they were able to sell stock
and generate huge proceeds from their
equity issuance. So they had, you know,
back in 2022, they had billions of
dollars of cash on their balance sheet
because they were able to raise so much
money by selling their stock.
But then their as they've they've
quickly burned through their cash
balance. And over the past couple years,
their share price has been so low. It's
usually been only like$1 or $2 per
share. And when the share price is so
low, they sell a lot of shares, but they
are not even able to raise that much
capital. So they're they've been
basically only raising cash. They've
basically only been able to raise
capital as fast as they can burn it. So,
their cash balance has remained pretty
low over the past couple years, but they
at least today they have still been able
to raise enough cash each quarter uh to
not to avoid bankruptcy, but they're
really operating on the margin here
where they're living hand-to-mouth and
basically burning money almost as fast
as they can raise it. thus resulting in
a persistently low uh a persistently low
cash balance which puts the company
always in a precarious position.
So now uh let's look at the details of
their financial position. So as of the
end of the third quarter on September
30th, 2025, Plug Power had 166 million
of cash. They also had 1.2 2 billion
common shares outstanding. Subsequent to
the end of the third quarter, so in
October of 2025, they did a warrant
conversion where there was a bunch of
warrants that they had issued previously
where they then they converted those
warrants into stock and Plug Power
received some cash for that. Plug Power
received some cash as a result of this
conversion. So they raised $355 million
from this warrant conversion. But this
also increased their share counts. They
had to issue 340 million shares. So
their share counts increased from 1.2
billion to 1.55 billion. So just from
this one warrant conversion, their share
count increased by approximately 30%.
Now they did raise uh this did get them
some cash. So their cash balance it was
166 million at the end of the third
quarter. they got this $355 million from
the warning conversion. So that brings
their cash balance up to $521 million.
However, just in the first nine months
of 2025, they already burned $500
million. And that's even despite them
running down their inventory. So they
are burning cash at a rate of like $650
million a year approximately. So this
$500 million of cash that they have now
is probably only going to get them
through the first half of 2026 at which
point they are going to need to raise
even more capital and probably probably
resulting in further dilution. Now Plug
Power they previously had um multiple
outstanding loans in November. So also
subsequent to quarter end in November of
2025 they refinanced um a bunch of their
loans. So they basically consolidated
their loans into one big loan of and
that that's basically the only loan they
have on their balance sheet now. And
this is a $431 million loan that has a
that is a convertible bond. So that this
loan can convert into stock at a $3
strike price and it carries a 7%
interest rate. So uh but it does not
mature until 2033. So that's eight years
away. So they do in addition, you know,
to their massive cash burn, they also
have this massive loan that they're
eventually going to have to repay, but
the maturity is pretty far out. So this
is not really um this is not really an
an imminent uh risk for the company, but
just something to keep in mind.
And now finally, we're going to discuss
in a little bit greater greater detail
that
this AI data center narrative that Ryan
alluded to at the um that Ryan alluded
to earlier in the video. So on November
10th, Plug Power put out this press
release saying
Plug Power to generate over $270 million
through monetization of electricity
rights and operational efficiencies
supports major US data center buildup.
So obviously now with AI and everything
and there's all these data center
companies building new data centers to
support AI and this is kind of the
hottest investment has been the hottest
investment theme over the past couple
years and Plug Power wants to jump on
this bag bandwagon and pretend like
there's some kind of AI beneficiary. But
if you read the uh the details of the
deal, it's all very vague. So they say,
"Plug Power has signed a non-binding
letter of intent to monetize its
electricity rights in New York and one
other location and collaborate with a U
with U with a US data center developer.
The project developer is actively
expanding its data center platforms
across the country and Plug Power will
work with them to explore providing
auxiliary and backup solutions utilizing
plugs advanced fuel cell technology. So
there's kind of two aspects of this.
First is the monetization of Plug
Powers's electricity rights and the
second thing is they're potentially
looking at providing plug power hydrogen
fuel cells as backup auxiliary power. So
the first uh the first part of it, the
monetizing electricity rights. So Plug
Power was planning to build this green
hydrogen facility in New York. And the
the way that this green hydrogen
production facility would work is you
know you take water you basically put
electricity into it and then that turns
into hydrogen. So you need a lot of
electricity to operate a green hydrogen
production facility. So Plug Power they
secured contracts with the electric
utility companies in New York and that
electricity contracts that they had
secured they were intending to use for
their green hydrogen production. But now
they're saying there's this data center
company that really wants to build this
data center in New York and they need
electricity and there's I guess a
shortage of electricity. So Plug Power
is going to cancel its green hydrogen
production facility and then they will
um and then they will sell their power
they will sell their electricity
purchase contract at a premium to this
data center company. That I believe is
what they're saying. However, this is a
non-binding letter of intent. So nothing
has actually happened. The D this data
center, this unnamed data center
operator, they have not actually
committed to anything. They just signed
a piece of paper saying, "Oh, we'll look
into maybe purchasing Plug Powers's
electricity rate. Also, they say Plug
Power to generate over $275 million."
But this $275 million is very vague.
They say it is expected to generate more
than $275 million in liquidity
improvement through a combination of
asset monetization, release of
restricted cash, and reduced maintenance
expect uh and reduced maintenance
expenses. So, this is a very vague
statement. They get $275 million in
liquidity improvements. So, they're not
even going to get $275 million of cash
from this data center company. What it
sounds like is there's a bunch of costs
that are associated with building this
green hydrogen production facility in
New York. And if Plug Power cancels that
facility because they're instead going
to sell the electricity rates to this
data center company, well, that reduces
their obligations and the amount of
money that they would have to pay to
build that hydrogen production facility.
So that $275 million is not actually
cash that they're receiving. It sounds
like basically the savings that they
will acrue by cancelling the
construction of the green hydrogen
production facility. But again, this is
all none of this is guaranteed because
it's still just a non-binding letter
letter of intent. And then they say
we're going to explore potentially uh
this data center company is going to
explore potentially buying some plug
power fuel cell generators as backup
power for their data centers. But again,
it's a non-binding letter of intent. It
means almost nothing because no deal has
been signed. So overall, I think this is
basically a giant nothing burger. This
whole thing is probably BS because it's
just a non-binding letter of intent. Uh
so it's probably it may not even ever
come to fruition.
So Plug Power over the years, they have
had so many different narratives that
they've tried to sell. So this company
was founded all the way back in I think
like 1998. So it's been like almost this
company has been around for like more
than 25 years and they have tried to do
many different things. So first they
were going to make a first that they
they were going to make a stationary
hydrogen fuel cell generator. Then
they're going to make forklifts. Then
they're going to start producing their
own hydrogen. Then they're going to sell
electrolyers. Now they're doing they
have this non-binding letter of intent
with a data center company. They always
have a new narrative that they try to
get investors excited about to um to try
to increase their stock price. But every
single thing that they have ever tried
has resulted in massive losses because
hydrogen as a technology is not
economically viable. And we can see if
you want to understand the plug power
story, you just need to look at these
two charts. The first chart is Plug
Power stock price, which is basically,
you know, sometimes there's pumps.
Sometimes it'll it'll pump up for a few
months, but it always goes down. The
trend of Plug Power stock is always
going downwards. And the reason the
stock is always going down is because
the company loses so much money that
they have to issue they have to issue
new shares to fund their losses. And as
the share count explodes, uh this
dilution c puts downward pressure on the
stock price. And I expect this to
continue uh going forward. So that about
wraps it up for everything we had to
talk about plug power today. As always,
if you have any opinions or thoughts
about plug power, please let us know in
the comments section below. And we will
see you all on next week's video.
